article.title: Hydrostatic-pressure effects on the pseudogap in slightly doped YBa2Cu3O7-δ single crystals

multiple_choice_question.text: Which curve in Figure 1 represents the temperature dependence of resistivity (ρ) for a YBa<sub>2</sub>Cu<sub>3</sub>O<sub>7-δ</sub> single crystal at a pressure of 1.05 GPa?
What method is used in Figure 1 to determine the pseudogap temperature (T*)?
choices: Extrapolation of the linear part of the curve to ρ = 0
Finding the temperature at which ρ starts to deviate from linear behavior at high temperatures

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 2 depict about the YBa<sub>2</sub>Cu<sub>3</sub>O<sub>6.5</sub> single crystal?
choices: Temperature dependence of resistivity at different pressures
Pressure dependence of lnρ at two different temperatures

multiple_choice_question.text: At which temperature does the pressure dependence of lnρ deviate from linearity in Figure 2?
What does the shaded area in Figure 3 represent?
choices: The width of the resistive transition (ΔT)

multiple_choice_question.text: How is the critical temperature (T<sub>c</sub>) determined in Figure 3?
choices: By extrapolating the linear part of the resistive transition to ρ(T<sub>c</sub>) = 0
By finding the temperature at the peak of the curve
By measuring the temperature at which ρ = 0

multiple_choice_question.text: What is plotted on the y-axis of Figure 4?
What fluctuation region is represented by the straight lines in Figure 4?
What does the crossover temperature (T<sub>o</sub>) signify in Figure 5?
choices: The temperature at which the pseudogap opens
The temperature at which the coherence length (ξ) becomes equal to the distance between conducting layers (d)
The temperature at which the superconducting gap closes

multiple_choice_question.text: Which theoretical model describes the data above T<sub>o</sub> in Figure 5?
What does Figure 6 illustrate about the YBa<sub>2</sub>Cu<sub>3</sub>O<sub>6.5</sub> single crystal under pressure?
choices: The increase of T<sub>c</sub> with pressure is independent of the oxygen content
The coherence length (ξ<sub>c</sub>(0)) and the distance between conducting layers (d<sub>1</sub>) decrease with increasing pressure
The pseudogap temperature (T*) remains constant under pressure

multiple_choice_question.text: At approximately what pressure does a peculiarity appear in the pressure dependence of ξ<sub>c</sub>(0) and d<sub>1</sub>?
What does the slope (a*) of the linear part in the inset of Figure 7 determine?
Which equation is used to fit the data in Figure 7 across the entire temperature range?
What is being plotted against the inverse of temperature (1/T) in Figure 8?
The best fit to the experimental data in Figure 8 is obtained for which value of D*?
What does the linear behavior of the pseudogap (Δ*) below T<sub>pair</sub> in Figure 9 indicate?
choices: The presence of strong electron-phonon coupling
The formation of fluctuating Cooper pairs (FCP)

multiple_choice_question.text: How does the shape of the Δ*(T) curve change with increasing pressure in Figure 9?
choices: The curve becomes steeper at all temperatures.
The curve changes noticeably at high temperatures but remains almost unchanged at low temperatures.
The curve shifts uniformly upwards with no change in shape.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the temperature T<sub>pair</sub> in Figure 10?
choices: It marks the onset of the pseudogap.
It signifies the superconducting transition temperature.
It separates the regimes dominated by strongly bound bosons (SBB) and fluctuating Cooper pairs (FCP).
It represents the temperature at which the coherence length equals the interplanar distance.

multiple_choice_question.text: What happens to the slope (α<sub>max</sub>) of the high-temperature maximum in the Δ*(T) curves with increasing pressure in Figure 10?
choices: The slope initially increases and then decreases.

multiple_choice_question.text: What parameter related to the pseudogap is plotted against pressure (P) in Figure 11?
What can be concluded from the similar pressure dependencies of Δ*(T<sub>mf</sub>) and D* in Figure 11?
choices: The increase of Δ* with pressure is solely due to the increase in T<sub>c</sub>.
The coupling strength in the cuprate increases with increasing pressure.
The electron-phonon interaction weakens with pressure.
